subject: Initial D-Bus interface
commitMessage:
Initial D-Bus interface

This sets up an initial D-Bus interface without any real functionality.
It doesn't interact with any storage hardware yet.

The yaml files are included temporarily until the
phosphor-dbus-interfaces review is complete:
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/48636

The .clang-tidy file has been removed because clang-tidy can't filter
out the generated files. It should be re-enabled when we no longer need
to generate the D-Bus sources in this repo.

Signed-off-by: John Edward Broadbent <jebr@google.com>
Change-Id: If704e69ef7225257efc7c865424df4421999f62d
Signed-off-by: John Wedig <johnwedig@google.com>

comments.message:
Patch Set 1:

(6 comments)

I've pointed out some things that will need to change, due to design doc feedback that we received since this commit was first created.

William and Brandon, this is the first of a series of commits that we've had queued up for a while. I'm guessing we should make these changes now, to align with the design doc?

Patch Set 1:

Do we really need to bundle the CLs as topic? or can they be hashtags instead.

Bundling changes as topic makes it so we can't submit one without all going in at the same time

Patch Set 2:

(12 comments)

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> Do we really need to bundle the CLs as topic? or can they be hashtags instead.
> 
> Bundling changes as topic makes it so we can't submit one without all going in at the same time

bmcweb uses the wip topics as a way to signal to reviewers that the code is not ready for detailed review. And removing the topic signals that your code is ready for reviewers. It is only a conventional. 
The hashtag is probably the way to go.

Thanks for the quick reviews. Let us know if you find anything that needs attention.

Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)

Setting to back to WIP

Patch Set 4:

For reference, here's the corresponding phosphor-dbus-interfaces gerrit review with the yaml files: https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/48636

Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

looks good to me

(5 comments)

Looks fine overall, we can start with this and continue the work.

looks good to me

Patch Set 16:

FYI, I uploaded a new patchset because I needed to fix a couple typos with the dbus name in main.cpp as well as a typo in the interface.yaml file.
Change has been successfully merged by John Wedig
print to std::err instead to be capture by the journal.

- cerr is only captured in syslog when the process is started by systemd
- when a process is started by systemd both stdout, and stderr are captured in syslog

The end state of logging is to explicitly write to syslog (using sd_journal_send) in a way that is redfish event log compatible. imho

cerr does make sense for stubs so I will change it and add comments inditing this is stub.
Thanks for the feedback, let me know if you see anything else.
The object path and bus name will need to change, per the design doc review.

I agree, we need update the code to match the design doc. 

Does it have to be this commit? This commit is blocking a couple of big changes, and it might be faster if this could be fixed in parallel. On the other hand it is related to the dbus interface, so we could do it in this change. I see the pros and cons.

To avoid forgetting about this issue I created. 
https://github.com/openbmc/estoraged/issues/1
This seems like a trivial change that can be made now.
Add `src/` `include/` structure to make it easier to manage the files.
Done. Take a look at what we have now.

i don't actually know where the requirement is from, but we are using it for all Google projects. https://github.com/openbmc/google-misc/blob/master/meson.build

Also, there is no reason why new project shouldn't be using C++20. We are also moving all Google projects to C++20

On reflection, I will add the meson restriction. It is better to be unnecessary strict, and return a meson error, then fail in a new and undocumented way, because of outdated meson.

I can't think of any reason, but maybe Wedig knows something I don't. He set this up, and he is doing the libcryptsetup integration. I think he will be fine with it, but lets double check.
I didn't have any reason to prefer c++17. I just copied it from somewhere else that probably should've been using c++20, as well.
this should be going to `phosphor-dbus-interface` unless there was a discussion in upstream about this already.

Make sense, I am setting this to WIP, until we have something planned.
Thanks
I removed the yaml files from this review. I have a pending review in phosphor-dbus-interfaces: https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/48636
I'm not sure whether we want to say eMMC in the description fields, since eStoraged could potentially be used for other types of devices later.
Per the design doc review, the DevicePassword parameter should be removed from all the D-Bus methods here. eStoraged will use a one-way hash to generate the device password.
if we are generating the devicePassword, we probably don't need it on the interface?
This parameter will need to become something more generic, e.g. eraseType

I agree. I would like you feedback on this the pending change below.

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/estoraged/+/48606/1/xyz/openbmc_project/eStoraged.interface.yaml
This will still require a password parameter, so that we can generate the device password.
I think I understand, change DevicePassword to a general password similar to format?
Yes, DevicePassword should be removed everywhere in this file.
This arguments in this file need to match the *.interface.yaml file. This doesn't build, does it?
Are we supposed to start with lower-case letters? i.e. "password" in this case?
Change the password parameters throughout this whole file.
I tried, but I don't think I can do that, since the base class doesn't use const.

add a meson.build in the include folder.

and have

```
eStoraged_headers = include_directories('.')
```

instead.

I am not sure if we want a namespace called openbmc?

Maybe just `estoraged` instead?

um, is this just to make sure that meson doesn't complain?

I would just remove it here and the function.

```
void eStoraged::format(std::vector<uint8_t>)
```

I assume gcc complains that password is not used.
This "usage" trick it okay with me.

Yeah, I was just trying to silence the 'unused variable' error. At the time, I forgot that you can just remove the parameter name to accomplish the same thing. I made this change throughout this file.
can we have the final name here?

I wasn't sure whether to do this now or later, but since you asked about the full bus name, I squashed another commit into this one. It adds a few arguments to this main file, which I use to complete the bus name.
this is probably not always true. Make this configurable?
As discussed offline, we have the -b option for this.

same here.

If we want to use `fmt/format.h`, you can do.

```
 std::string path = fmt::format("/xyz/openbmc_project/storage/{}", deviceName);
```
Done. I'm using the + operator for now.
I would think clang-format would not like 80+ chars per line - it looks like unit tests are possibly not enabled on this repo yet?
You should be able to remove `eStoraged_dbus_headers` with the change below.
You might not need this dependency if you aren't using anything common in your yaml files. It looks like you don't.
Oh, good call. I removed it.
nit: meson treats args[1]... as sources, so you don't need the extra array layer here.
You should add `include_directories: eStoraged_dbus_headers` so that dependents don't need to know this detail.
Is this variable casing with capital `S` going to be consistent? The top-level meson.build doesn't use it.
Hmm, you're right. I changed src/meson.build to use the capital 'S', as well.
